firstChapter.htmlHeader: Immunizations - seasonal influenza: Summary
firstChapter.htmlStringContent:
• Influenza is an acute viral infection of the respiratory tract. Influenza types A and B are responsible for most cases of clinical illness in the UK.
  • In healthy people, seasonal influenza is usually a self-limiting disease with recovery in 2–7 days. However, in older people and those in clinical risk groups, it can result in serious complications such as pneumonia, meningitis, encephalitis, or death.
  • Seasonal influenza immunization is recommended for people at increased risk of complications, including
    • All people 50 years of age and older.
    • All people aged between 6 months to under 50 years who are in a clinical risk group, such as people with chronic respiratory, heart, kidney, liver, or neurological disease; people with diabetes mellitus; people who are immunosuppressed or immunocompromised, pregnant women, people with morbid obesity and people who are on the COVID-19 shielded patient list and members of their household.
    • People living in long-stay residential and nursing homes or other long-stay care facilities.
    • All school year groups up to year 7.
  • To reduce the risk of transmission to people in vulnerable groups, seasonal influenza immunization is recommended in certain healthy individuals, including:
    • Household contacts of people who are immunocompromised.
    • Healthcare and social care workers directly involved in patient care.
  • Seasonal influenza immunization is also recommended for people in receipt of a carer's allowance, or those who are the main carer of an elderly or disabled person whose welfare may be at risk if the carer falls ill.
  • Seasonal influenza vaccine should be given annually, ideally between September and early November.
    • The choice of seasonal influenza vaccine depends on the age of the person, whether they are in a clinical risk group, and whether there are any contraindications or cautions to the vaccine.
  • If a person has an egg allergy:
    • In-hospital immunization should be arranged if a child has had a confirmed anaphylactic reaction to egg which has required intensive care management, referral to a paediatric immunologist or allergy specialist.
    • For all other egg-allergic children, Fluenz Tetra can be given in primary care if there are no contraindications.
    • Adults with a history of severe anaphylaxis which has previously required intensive care management in hospital should be referred to an immunologist or allergy specialist for assessment for in-hospital immunization.
    • For adults with less severe egg allergy, an inactivated influenza vaccine with a very low ovalbumin content (less than 0.06 micrograms per 0.5 mL dose), or the egg-free cell-based quadrivalent influenza vaccine (QIVc), Flucelvax Tetra, should be given.
  • Adverse effects are common after influenza vaccination and usually disappear within 1–2 days without needing treatment. These include:
    • Pain, swelling, redness, or induration at the injection site.
    • Low-grade fever, malaise, or fatigue.
  • Vaccination should be repeated annually for people who are eligible as part of the national influenza immunization programme.
